Award.AwardTitle: Patent Licensing, Technology Transfer, and Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Patent reform is an important policy topic in the United States today, particularly in the software, technology, and service industries where Intellectual Property (IP) is a key asset. High litigation costs in patent infringement cases favor licensing agreements and financial settlements, regardless of the actual merits of the case. Some argue that non-practicing entities, who have no production interests, harm innovative activity though aggressive licensing and costly litigation. Others believe that non-practicing entities facilitate innovation by licensing to companies that develop and manufacture new products, creating jobs and economic growth. This research will survey companies to gain information on the true value of patent licensing, with a focus on licenses from non-practicing entities. Data will be collected on how often licensing actually leads to innovation, technology transfer, and new technical knowledge. The results will inform patent reform as Congress and numerous state legislatures require reliable to maintain the strength of American innovation system.

Detailed company surveys are among the best options for eliciting new information in patent policy research, given that most patent disputes do not progress to the litigation stage and therefore are not captured in existing legal databases. In fact, some 90% of patent enforcement activity may take place outside of court proceedings. Further, companies are unwilling to discuss agreements publicly because of non-disclosure agreements and fears of retaliation. This research will result in the creation of a large data set that can be used for other projects focusing on patent licensing and royalty agreements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on non-practicing entities (NPEs)?patent holders that engage in assertion activities as opposed to making products?and the relationship between ex post licensing and actual innovation. Scholars had previously argued about the role of NPEs, with some arguing that patent lawsuits and the demands from NPEs indicate inefficiencies in the patent system, while others asserted that NPEs play a useful intermediary role. However, legal scholars and economists studying the societal effects of NPEs on innovation had been stymied by a lack of information.

 

To address these significant gaps in the literature, the project team established the first comprehensive study of how American businesses respond to patent licensing demands, using a rigorous methodological approach to analyze NPE activity that had never been used before. Specifically, the project team developed a set of markers to search for evidence of innovation flowing from ex post patent licensing. They then surveyed product-producing companies to determine how often patent license demands actually led to new products or innovative activity. Expanding beyond the original scope of a pilot study that focused solely on in-house attorneys? experiences with patent assertions and ex post licensing, the team created a full study?funded exclusively by the NSF?that allowed it to address a broader and more representative sample of American businesses. This funding opportunity allowed for collaboration with survey experts at the Indiana University Center for Survey Research (CSR) and Dun & Bradstreet (D&B). In May 2017, the team sent the full survey to more than 30,000 companies and obtained responses from 1,718 companies across five industries: chemistry, computers, energy, life sciences, and transportation.

 

Ultimately, the project found that very few patent license demands actually led to new products or innovation. Instead, most patent demands involved payment to NPEs for licensees to continue what they were already doing. These results cast doubt on the argument that NPEs serve as efficient middlemen who bring patented ideas to those who can make use of them. These findings validate the original hypothesis that ?the efficient middleman? claim did not hold true. Results indicate that NPE licensing demands hardly ever led to innovation by the targeted firm, that none of the indicators of technology transfer commonly accompanied patent licensing demands, and finally that NPE demands infrequently appeared alongside transfers of knowledge or personnel, the creation of joint ventures, or the development of new products. Thus, the study helps answer the broader question or whether or not NPEs serve as a ?tax? on innovation. Ultimately, the study suggests that the patent enforcement system is not itself a driver of new products, technology or personnel transfer, or the establishment of joint ventures. Thus, the project provides a data-driven value assessment of a common claim that NPEs serve as a bridge between inventors and those in a place to produce something derived from that invention.

 

These results can contribute to policy debates about the patent system and highlighting the complex reality of patent licensing demands in the literature about this topic. The study points out the differences among various types of NPEs and the accompanying variations in their rates of innovation or knowledge transfer when they licensed patents. It also confirms prior literature that the patent system functions differently in different industries (for example - that the energy industry sees far more new products resulting from patent assertions relative to other industries). This adds to the argument that policy experts need to acknowledge the reality of industry differences in order to fully analyze the patent licensing and assertion environment.
